content.description:
From the Orton Guide, "Continuously overhanging face climbing on edges and liebacks.  Powerful and technical route with rounded slab finish for the last 25 ft.  Excellent route."

 There is potential for awkward (mind your ankles!) falls into bulges moving toward 3rd bolt.  Lots of potential for safe big air higher on the route.  Top out slab is VERY dirty.  Tred lightly.
content.location: Two routes left of Joy Luck Club.  Look for a chain on second bolt.

content.description: Long moves between mostly positive holds.  You'll pull down on a bit of everything and encounter more than one crux along the way.  The actual crux will likely depend on climbing style/size etc.  Movement is quite fun once you get the sequences worked out.
content.location: Directly left of Straight No Chaser.  Belay is not ideal, given angle of landing.

content.description: Start on Fragile Life and climb through low crux to the ledge (bolts 6/7).  Traverse left into Joy Luck Club, do a few moves at the bulge, and clip the bolt with a fixed chain.  Finish Joy Luck Club.
content.location: Fragile Life and Joy Luck Club are the two right most routes on the wall that start from the ground rather than the slab.

content.description:
After a short slab and bulge, launch into a relentless overhang, traversing right (crux?) about six bolts up.  The first half features relatively straightforward reaches between good underclings and sidepulls, while the second half has far more holds to choose between, making it easy to get off track.  Savor any holds you can pull down on, because there aren't many of them! 

  There is an optional 5.7 second pitch that tops out.
content.protection: Bolts (about 9), two-bolt anchor at the top.
content.location:
JLC is on the right hand side of the overhanging wall.  It has chains on two of its bolts and a rightward traverse about halfway up. 

  You can easily set a toprope on this route.  Hike to the top and rappel off a pair of glue-ins (the correct anchor is just below a large bent cold shut) down to the lip of the overhang, where there are two sets of anchors next to each other.  The JLC anchor is the one that's to the right and slightly lower, and it's directly across from a tall fir tree.  If you set a TR, make sure to put in lots of directionals, as the route traverses a decent amount in addition to being overhung.

content.description: A shallow slab and a few bolts bring you to the start of a steep slab that is dipping at a weird angle and makes for an interesting lead. When you hit a blank section try to mantle and grab a nice hold (possible crux). The head wall is slightly overhanging on good holds. Single rope rappel.
content.protection: Bolts to fixed anchors with rap rings.
content.location: Locate a tree midway up in the bowl shaped area, then look for the obviously cleaned bolted route to the left of the tree.

content.description: Climb slab through namesake flake.  Continue up into steeper pumpy terrain.  Brilliant variety and one-of-a-kind sequences.
content.location: Last route on the right before routes move onto slab.  Easily identified by the very large flake about 4 bolts up.

content.description: From the Orton guide:  "An onslaught of trickery and unusual steep friction and face moves on a unique climb."
content.location: Starts at the belay station between Dire Straights and Intrigue

content.description: The name says it all! Locate the lowest pair of anchors on the eastern most side of the north slab(for belay). Run up the easy slab clipping a few bolts if desired heading towards the blankest section of slab in the bowl area. A tricky mantle right off the low angle slab sets the tone for the rest of the climb. Pitch 2: 5.9 looks easy, but keeps you on your toes, at the 3rd bolt dog left, pull a bulge and continue on easy terrain to the summit.
content.protection: Bolts to fixed anchors (no rap rings).
content.location: Look for a tree midway up on the northern slab/bowl area. Now look  down and to its right at a very clean and smooth section of rock. A suggested way down as there are no rings on these anchors is to scramble down the summit to your right (there's a bolt if you get worried) and find a pair of anchors with rings. Two rope rappel, or eye a pair of intermediate chains for single.

content.description: This wall is in the shade until the late afternoon, and trees keep much of it shady even later.  The left side of this wall has some of the steepest climbing at Flagstone.
